text: President Donald Trump’s brother is asking a New York City judge to prevent the president’s niece from publishing a tell-all book, which is expected to be released later this month https://t.co/1MkAKKjxG3

text: Review: Jon Stewart's new political comedy, "Irresistible," is extremely condescending and unrelentingly cynical. https://t.co/olwburbRLY

text: With decisions on college football looming, the Tribune's @TeddyGreenstein and @sryantribune talk scheduling, testing and whether there should be college football at all. https://t.co/e5rumuc1aK

text: What changes when Chicago and the rest of Illinois enter the next phase of reopening on Friday? Your guide to shopping, restaurants, bars, entertainment venues, child care and more. https://t.co/ii5GavZxGt

text: MLS returns July 8 with a 54-game tournament. Here’s what that means for the Chicago Fire. https://t.co/WVa1URlnaZ

name: chicagotribune
text:
Black people have gone by many names in the U.S. Lately, the term BIPOC is spreading on social media. Here’s where it comes from.

From The New York Times. https://t.co/0cjg3RscGs

text: Northwestern University is offering buyouts to 4,000 staff members in an attempt to cut costs because of the coronavirus pandemic. https://t.co/E70RTXb5eJ

text: The announcement of a shortened season by MLB came while more players continue to test positive for the coronavirus — including at least seven on the Philadelphia Phillies alone. https://t.co/hglm7Os7cn

name: chicagotribune
text: A Wisconsin state senator was attacked and statues, including one of an anti-slavery activist who fought for the Union in the Civil War, were torn town in Madison overnight by protesters. https://t.co/p3czWNZOPO

name: chicagotribune
text: Chicago has received more than 7,000 emergency calls for fireworks disturbances so far this year, compared with only 842 last year during the same time period, a 736% increase. https://t.co/vDnnbRrLDR

name: chicagotribune
text: If you encounter a social distancing ambassador along Chicago's Lakefront Trail, remember, they're doing it for you, writes columnist @MarySchmich https://t.co/QE8KeW2UOU

name: chicagotribune
text: Illinois is on the brink of entering phase four of its reopening. But columnist @RexHuppke isn't so sure we're really ready. https://t.co/HQ4ZJoLDNs

name: chicagotribune
text: The FBI determined the noose found in NASCAR driver Bubba Wallace’s garage stall at Talladega had been there since at least October. The rope was referred to as a noose, but can be used as a handle when closing the door. https://t.co/6ujWKpLI6r

name: chicagotribune
text: Illinois will enter phase 4 of its coronavirus reopening plan Friday. Here’s a guide to what’s allowed. https://t.co/20sPpNbQCW

text: Following multiple allegations of sexual impropriety, Chris D’Elia has been dropped by both his agent and his manager. https://t.co/IvG4DC8wcZ

text: Kathleen Lombardo’s killing had a profound impact on the late true crime writer Michelle McNamara, who was a teenager growing up in Oak Park at the time. https://t.co/OaCPOGY1vy

name: chicagotribune
text: The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia said in a 2-1 ruling that the Justice Department's decision to abandon the case against Michael Flynn settles the matter. https://t.co/Nwk3yMTtNL

name: chicagotribune
text: Crowds outside the Wisconsin State Capitol tore down two statues and attacked a state senator amid protests following the arrest of a Black man who was at a restaurant with a megaphone and a baseball bat. https://t.co/7WUVW6TDJV

name: chicagotribune
text: The Shedd Aquarium and Brookfield Zoo will reopen to members July 1 and to the rest of the public in the following days. The Lincoln Park Zoo reopens to the public starting Monday. https://t.co/0pDhEttRqE

name: chicagotribune
text: A Republican police reform bill was voted down in the U.S. Senate, with Democrats saying it doesn't go far enough. A Democratic bill in the House is headed for a vote Thursday, with a growing base of mayors and industry leaders signing a letter of support. https://t.co/J7lmVdGCub

name: chicagotribune
text:
RT @Nina_Metz: I talk with Chris Redd (@Reddsaidit) & Lisa Beasley (@lisabexperience) about their COVID-19 Protest Relief Fund. 

They are also among the Black performers who signed the open letter to Second City about racism at the theater; we talked about that as well. https://t.co/91qhEHRZyJ https://t.co/U9rQhIZhN3

name: chicagotribune
text: RT @HannahMLeone: Our story has been updated from public comment, which featured an unusual number of Chicago aldermen (falling on both sides of school police issue) and pastor Marvin Hunter, the great-uncle of Laquan McDonald. CPS Chief of Safety and Security now presenting recent survey results. https://t.co/Rx5xi6vi6P https://t.co/kPzVnpfDYP

name: chicagotribune
text: Gov. J.B. Pritzker says he has no plan to ask visitors from states with rising coronavirus infection rates to quarantine upon arrival in Illinois, diverging from a strategy seen in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, which issued a joint travel advisory https://t.co/uItQRwax7b

name: chicagotribune
text: “Saturday Night Live” cast member Chris Redd and fellow Chicago comedian Lisa Beasley have set up a COVID-19 Protest Relief Fund, looking to raise donations geared to help people who have been protesting and are having health issues as a result https://t.co/kmdGqU5Pmr

name: chicagotribune
text: RT @chitribopinions: Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot will have a battle royale on her hands during revived contract negotiations with the Fraternal Order of Police. Trying to retract contract provisions will be difficult, if not impossible, the Tribune Editorial Board writes. https://t.co/RhsyFk7z4F

name: chicagotribune
text:
RT @HeidiStevens13: It’s Pride Week in traditionally conservative Wheaton, just a few months after a school canceled author and LGBTQ champion Robin Stevenson’s talk.

“This is a Wheaton I really never thought I’d see, with all the rainbows and love and support.”

https://t.co/LlTO1qWmzz

name: chicagotribune
text: Gov. J.B. Pritzker announced $50 million in state grants for broadband projects across Illinois. The grants will expand internet access for thousands of businesses, homes and farms. https://t.co/ib8C11qpzQ

name: chicagotribune
text: Starting Friday, Illinois health and fitness clubs can open at half their capacity with group classes of up to 50 people. But in Chicago, tighter restrictions, including a 25% capacity limit and requirement to wear a mask indoors, have some owners worried. https://t.co/grX9XyY90W

name: chicagotribune
text:
“If there was really strong mask-wearing across the whole country for a month, along with distancing, we would drop this so far,” an epidemiologist told columnist @RexHuppke.

If you don’t want the country to close right back up, wear masks, Huppke writes. https://t.co/I0ubTCZVuL

name: chicagotribune
text:
Leaving your home for any reason involves some level of risk of contracting COVID-19.

If you're planning to take a trip this summer anyway, we gathered expert safety advice on flying, road trips and other vacation concerns you may have. https://t.co/rUrRDCKAXy

name: chicagotribune
text: Wisconsin’s governor has activated the National Guard following a chaotic night that included protesters tearing down two statues outside the state Capitol and an attack on a state senator https://t.co/vtN4uVZZfq
